intro: Aniseia mexicana, commonly known as Mexican anise, is a herbaceous plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its fruit, similar to that of fennel, is used in traditional medicine for its digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Aniseia mexicana thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a hardy plant suitable for cultivation in temperate climates.
